children.subject:
Not sure about 182, but 126 was honestly fairly low workload — I’d say about 5-7 hours a week outside of lecture to finish the HW and lab. Since you’re pretty comfortable with 70 probability material, I think a significant portion of 126 will feel like review or just an extension of concepts you’ve already seen (e.g. probability basics, Markov chains, estimation). 

However, if you’re taking the class in order to get really good at probability you could still put way way more time into it. Understanding the concepts in 126 at a deep level is honestly much harder than doing well grade-wise (since the curve is pretty lenient), so that would mean reading and annotating the weekly course notes, going to office hours, etc. While you may not spend much time working on actual class work, the concepts will end up taking a lot of mental effort to get through which may be why people find it so tough!

history.content:
I'm a Econ + CS double major. I'm debating between EECS 126 and CS W182 (if I can get off its waitlist). I'll also be taking CS 170 and two econ upperdivs to round out my schedule. Relevant courses I've taken before are CS 70, Data 100, and CS 61B.

What's the workload of EECS 126 compared to that of CS W182? I did pretty well on the probability portion of CS 70 and have been going through the first four chapters B&T EECS 126 textbook. I have no prior ML experience outside of Data 100 lol.

Can anyone shed some light on the workloads of any of the classes I mentioned?
history.subject: Course schedule advice - EECS 126 vs CS W182
